title: Critérium du Dauphiné 2024: Route, TV guide and everything you need to know
content:
Cyclist
Critérium du Dauphiné 2024: Route, TV guide and everything you need to know

The Critérium du Dauphiné 2024 will run from the 2th-9th June in the former Dauphiné province in southeast France, which is now mostly made up of the Isère, Drôme and Hautes-Alpes departments. The race typically hosts Tour de France favourites as a final warm-up race due to its proximity to the Tour and has previously been won by riders including Bernard Hinault, Bradley Wiggins and Chris Froome.

On his way to doubling up on Tour de France glory, Jonas Vingegaard secured victory in the 2023 edition of the Critérium du Dauphiné ahead of Adam Yates and Ben O’Connor.

The lineup for the 2024 edition is depleted following the crashes at Itzulia Basque Country earlier this year. Jonas Vingegaard will not be making an appearance, but Primož Roglič and Remco Evenepoel will renew their rivalry on French roads. Other contenders include the Roglič’s Bora-Hansgrohe helpers Sasha Vlasov and Jai Hindley as well as Spaniards Carlos Rodríguez and Juan Ayuso. All of these hopefuls are set to compete at the Tour de France later this year.

Critérium du Dauphiné 2024: Key information

  • Date: 2nd-9th June
  • Start: Saint-Pourçain-sur-Sioule
  • Finish: Plateau des Glières
  • Distance: 1187.6km
  • Live UK TV coverage: Eurosport, Discovery+
  • 2023 winner: Jonas Vingegaard (Jumbo-Visma)

Critérium du Dauphiné 2024: Route and stage-by-stage preview

The 2024 Dauphiné begins in the Allier départements with a circuit stage around Saint-Pourçain-sur-Sioule. From the north-westerly corner of the historic Dauphiné region, the race moves eastwards with a long uphill finish at the Col de la Loge. Stage 3 will push the peloton southwards into Haute-Loire with an undulating stage to Les Estables.

The clocks will be out en force for Stage 4’s individual time-trial in the Loire département between Saint-Germain-Laval and Neulise. This 34.4km long race of truth will provide a sense of GC hierarchy before Stage 5’s voyage into wine country in Saint-Priest. Stage 6 will take the riders into the Alps proper with a sharp finale to the Collet d’Allevard (11.2km at 8.1%). The climbing continues for Stage 7 with a summit finish at Samoëns 1600 (10km at 9.3%).

The 2024 Dauphiné closes off with one final Alpine test in the Haute-Savoie with an arrival in Plateau des Glières (9.4km at 7.1%). Here the winner will be crowned.

Stage 1: Saint-Pourçain-sur-Sioule > Saint-Pourçain-sur-Sioule, 172.5km

The opening stage of the 2024 Critérium du Dauphiné takes the riders on a loop around Saint-Pourçain-sur-Sioule. The stage offers a rolling profile with the chance of a reduced bunch sprint. The opening day of the Dauphiné, however, can’t be second guessed. Sometimes, a breakaway can go all the way.

Stage 2: Gannat > Col de la Loge, 142km

The second stage will guide the riders from Gannat, over some categorised climbs towards the finale at the Col de la Loge. The mountaintop has never been frequented by a pro race, but this is set to change at the Dauphiné. The final 20km progress like a staircase, with the gradients fluctuating up to 6%. This should give us a signal of who has decent legs after a long dry patch of stage racing.

Stage 3: Celles-sur-Durolle > Les Estables, 181.7km

The third day of racing takes the riders toward the southern frontiers of the Dauphiné region. The profile relentlessly rises and falls in the latter half of the day, culminating in a short 3.8km-long kicker at the end. This stage reeks of breakaway success, however, we could see some GC riders try to take an early jump on the two favourites of Evenepoel and Roglic.

Stage 4: Cours – Saint-Germain-Laval > Neulise, 34.4km

It’s time to get the ITT legs on for Stage 4’s race against the clock in the Loire département. The terrain looks rolling, but not too much to eliminate the rouleur-type engines. There’s a sequence of very technical corners around halfway through the course as the parcours takes the riders across the Loire river.

Stage 5: Amplepuis > Saint-Priest, 167km

The fifth stage proposes a ‘flatter’ profile, at least for Dauphiné standards. At the 100km marker, the race dives down towards the Roman jazz town of Vienne where the peloton crosses the Rhône. The stage will finish in an eastern suburb of Lyon, so the peloton will hopefully be met with a ferocious crowd in the culinary capital of France.

Stage 6: Hauterives > Le Collet d’Allevard, 174.1km

Stage 6 enters the Alps. The Col du Granier serves as an entrée before the big finale. The last climb of the Collet d’Allevard sits at 11.2km in length at an average gradient of 8.1%. With these stats, it’s worthy of its hors catégorie status. Joaquim Rodríguez won a stage up at the summit back in 2011 when the race went by its former monicker of the Dauphiné Libéré.

Stage 7: Albertville > Samoëns 1600, 155.3km

Stage 7 sees the riders enter familiar climbing country. The start in Albertville has been used many times in the history of the Tour de France. From the Savoie capital, the race turns uphill over the Col des Saisies and the Col de la Ramaz. The summit finish at Samoëns sits just next to the Swiss border, but its slopes haven’t been graced since the 2021 edition. The 10km long approach averages a mean 9.3% gradient. This will provide a real sting in the tail of this alpine odyssey.

Stage 8: Thônes > Plateau des Glières, 160.6km

The final showdown takes the riders through Haute-Savoie, right in the heart of Tartiflette country. The road is rarely flat as the riders approach the tough final 80km. The 9.4km long climb of the Plateau des Glières averages out at a 7.1% gradient, making it a fitting farewell to the 2024 Critérium du Dauphiné. The Tour de France passed over the Plateau des Glières at the 2020 edition. There, the race passed over its gravel peak. It is unknown whether the gravel roads at the summit will be used at the 2024 Dauphiné.

Critérium du Dauphiné 2024: How to watch

The Critérium du Dauphiné will be shown throughout the week on Eurosport and Discovery+ in the UK and Europe. In the US, the racing will be shown on NBC Sports and Australia has broadcasting provided by SBS.

If it’s not being shown in your country, you may be able to watch coverage using a VPN – Virtual Private Network – which allows users to mask their IP address and watch geo-blocked content, provided they don’t need to pay for a subscription. This is also helpful for watching paid-for coverage while travelling abroad in countries without access.

One such example is ExpressVPN, which is very well reviewed, has specific advice for watching cycling and costs £5.36 per month with three months free. Other options include NordVPN, Surfshark and Kapersky.

  • Read more: How to watch cycling post-GCN

Live TV and streaming times

All times BST and subject to change by broadcasters

Stage 1: Saint-Pourçain-sur-Sioule > Saint-Pourçain-sur-Sioule, 172.5km

  • Discovery+: 14:00-16:00*

Stage 2: Gannat > Col de la Loge, 142km

  • Discovery+: 14:10-16:10*

Stage 3: Celles-sur-Durolle > Les Estables, 181.7km

  • Discovery+: 14:10-16:10
  • Eurosport 2: 14:10-16:00

Stage 4: Saint-Germain-Laval > Neulise, 34.4km

  • Discovery+: 14:10-16:10
  • Eurosport 2: 14:10-16:10

Stage 5: Amplepuis > Saint-Priest, 167km

  • Discovery+: 11:45-13:45
  • Eurosport 2: 11:45-13:45

Stage 6: Hauterives > Le Collet d’Allevard, 174.1km

  • Discovery+: 14:25-16:25

Stage 7: Albertville > Samoëns 1600, 155.3km

  • Discovery+: 12:05-14:05
  • Eurosport 2: TBC

Stage 8: Thônes > Plateau des Glières, 160.6km

  • Discovery+: 12:05-14:05

* Eurosport will not show live broadcasts from the Dauphiné on these days due to a clash with French Open coverage. Highlight packages will be available the following day on TV.
